p.s:
is a Portuguese Full Professor of
Entomology
at
Rutgers University
.

Fonseca grew up in
Coimbra
, Portugal .

She was the first member of her family to attend the
University of Coimbra
, where she studied
biology
,
biospeleology
and
geology
.
While enrolled in the university , she began teaching courses on biology and health to high schoolers in hope to get a doctorate and become a tenured professor in her alma mater .

The university offered her a summer program , at
Beaver Island
,
Michigan
where the
Central Michigan University Biological Station
was located .

After falling in love with an American education system , she switched programs to get her master â€™s degree at
Central Michigan University
, and in 1996 got her Ph.D. in
ecology
and
evolution
at the
University of Pennsylvania
following by
fellowship
with the
Smithsonian Institution
.

As a postdoc at the National Zoo Institute for Conservation and Biodiversity , she had studied
molecular biology
and
avian malaria
of endangered
endemic
Hawaiian birds as well as vectors of the
West Nile virus
, and by 1999 moved into the
medical entomology
field .
[ 1 ]

From 1999 to 2001 , Fonseca was a research associate at the
Walter Reed Army Medical Center
where she studied human malaria in
Kenya
and by 2001 accepted a position of geneticist at the Smithsonian Institution .

In 2004 , she became an Assistant Curator at the
Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University
and three years later joined
Rutgers University
where she served as tenure and then as full professor .
[ 1 ]

In October 2016 she became an Interim Director of the Center for Vector Biology and in July 2017 was promoted to Director .
[ 2 ]
Fromn 2015 to 2016 she was a
George E. Burch
fellow at the
National Zoological Park
.
[ 3 ]

In 1995 , while at the
University of Pennsylvania
, Fonseca studied
Simulium vittatum
, a species of black fly .
[ 4 ]

In 2001 , Fonseca along with Dennis Lapointe and
Robert Fleischer
conducted a study of
Culex quinquefasciatus
and its spread of avian malaria in
Hawaii
.

In the study they showed that this mosquito was introduced to the Hawaiian Islands in 1830 and exist on
The Big Island
,
Maui
and
Midway Atoll
.
[ 5 ]

The same year , Fonseca worked with
Daniel Strickman
of
Walter Reed Army Institute of Research
using
ND4
and
RAPD
analysis to study
haplotypes
of the subspecies of
Aedes japonicus
:
A. j. japonicus
and
A. j. yaeyamensis
at Japanese cities , comparing them with those on
Long
and
Shelter Islands
in the
United States
.

Her team also found the haplotypes of the species in
Manorville
and
Southold
,
New York
as well in
Connecticut
,
Maryland
,
Ohio
,
Pennsylvania
and in
New Egypt
and
Vernon Township , New Jersey
.
[ 6 ]

In 2004 , Fonseca ,
Francis Schaffner
and colleagues published an article in the journal
Science
regarding the species of mosquito
C. pipiens
and its role in the spread of viruses .
[ 7 ]

From May to October 2008 to 2011 , Fonseca ,
Randy Gaugler
and colleagues from
Rutgers University
had collected 73,828 female species of
Aedes albopictus
in
Mercer
and
Monmouth Counties
.
The 187 species out of 33,392 that were collected in Mercer County contained blood , while 219 out of 40,436 from Monmouth County had blood .

She also collected 14,989
Culex
species in the same counties , out of which only 745 contained blood .

The blood samples were from meals of the following mammals :
humans
( 52.12 % ) ,
cats
( 20.61 % ) , or
dogs
( 11.52 % ) as well as
opossums
( 4.24 % ) , gray squirrels ( 3.64 % ) ,
cottontail rabbits
( 1.21 % ) , and a
white-footed mouse
( 0.61 % ) .

In the study it was suggested by her and her team that 62 % of humans were bitten by
A. albopictus
in a suburban Monmouth , while the urban Mercer was at 43 % .

The study also suggests that the mosquito feeds on human blood mostly in August and in total collects 87 % of blood meals between July and October .
[ 8 ]

In 2011 she studied the subspecies of
C. pipiens
, which is known as
Culex pipiens pallens
as well as other members of the genus
Culex
:
C. quinquefasciatus
,
C. australicus
, and
C. globocoxitus
and issued a verdict that
Culex pipiens
is the only species that transmits
arboviruses
and
filariasis
.
[ 9 ]

She also studied
C. pipiens
and
C. restuans
for
vector
competence on their
spatial
and
temporal scales
.
[ 10 ]

In 2018 , Fonseca studied
longhorned tick
in
Bergen County
[ 11 ]
and
A. albopictus
, a species of
mosquito
which had become a common pest in
University Park , Maryland
.
[ 12 ]

In December that year , she proved that the longhorned tick can reproduce
asexually
[ 13 ]
and in 2019 she confirmed that the species had existed in New Jersey since 2013 .
[ 14 ]

During that year , Fonseca along with James Occi and Andrea Egizi published ,
[ 15 ]
a research paper on ticks in the
Journal of Medical Entomology
.

In it , they described 11 species of ticks , one of which was found throughout Asia -- and also in
New Jersey
.

The species that they collected were already known to
science
:
A. americanum
,
D. albipictus
,
D. variabilis
,
I. brunneus
,
I. cookei
,
I. dentatus
,
I. scapularis
and
I. texanus
.
[ 16 ]

She also was a campaigner for a tick surveillance
[ 17 ]
which eventually got introduced in
Monmouth County , New Jersey
.
[ 18 ]

In 1989 , Fonseca met her future husband , a professor of
immunology
, while attending the
University of Pennsylvania
.
Together they have two sons .

The family initially lived in
Bala Cynwyd , Pennsylvania
, but two years later Fronseca and her husband moved to the
Bethesda , Maryland
where he her husbvand accepted a position as a senior researcher at the
National Institutes of Health
. .
[ 1 ]
